factoid: Denísov’s squadron moved from the place where it had spent the night at dawn on the sixteenth of November.

The affair was not big.

The day was bright and sunny after a sharp night frost.

The news of victory was conveyed by the joyful expression on the faces of soldiers.

Nicholas Rostóv had spent that happy day in inactivity.

Denísov shouted, "Come here, Wostóv. Let’s dwink to dwown our gwief!"
Denísov had settled down by the roadside with a flask and some food.
The officers gathered round Denísov’s canteen.
The officers were eating.
The officers were talking.
One of the officers cried, "There! They are bringing another!"
One of the officers indicated a captive French dragoon.
The captive French dragoon was being brought in on foot by two Cossacks.
One of the Cossacks was leading by the bridle a fine large French horse.
The Cossack had taken the horse from the prisoner.
Denísov called out to the Cossacks, "Sell us that horse!"
The Cossacks replied, "If you like, your honor!"
The officers got up.
The officers stood round the Cossacks.
The officers stood round the prisoner.
The French dragoon was a young Alsatian.
The French dragoon spoke French with a German accent.
The French dragoon was breathless with agitation.
The French dragoon’s face was red.
When the French dragoon heard some French spoken, he at once began speaking to the officers.
The French dragoon addressed the first officer.
The French dragoon addressed the second officer.
The French dragoon said he would not have been taken.
The French dragoon said it was not his fault.

The French dragoon said he had told the corporal that the Russians were there.

The French dragoon did not quite grasp where he was.

The French dragoon imagined himself before his own officers.
